message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The renal biopsy shows a “lumpy bumpy” appearance, which is consistent with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The patient’s symptoms, including the rash on her face, also support this diagnosis. IgA nephropathy typically presents with hematuria, not cola-colored urine. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis presents with subendothelial or intramembranous immune complex deposits, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis presents with crescent formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The renal biopsy shows diffuse global endocapillary proliferation and a prominent subepithelial “hump.” This is consistent with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, which commonly occurs following a streptococcal infection, and can lead to hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. The recent rash on the face is also a common symptom of streptococcal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows the characteristic “humps“ of immune complexes in the glomerulus, which is consistent with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The patient had a rash on her face 4 weeks ago, which suggests a recent streptococcal infection.

We refer to the reference resource Medscape for help. The renal biopsy image shows a "lumpy-bumpy" appearance of the glomeruli which is characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The patient's recent history of facial swelling and a rash on her face suggests an underlying streptococcal infection. IgA nephropathy typically presents with microscopic hematuria and mesangial IgA deposits on biopsy. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis have distinct histological appearances that are not seen in this biopsy image.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recent rash and facial swelling suggests poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The renal biopsy image shows a characteristic “lumpy-bumpy” appearance due to deposition of immune complexes containing antibodies to streptococcal antigens. The other options have different histopathological characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of “cola-colored” urine, facial swelling, and a recent rash suggests post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is supported by the renal biopsy showing a “lumpy-bumpy” pattern of IgG and C3 deposition along the glomerular basement membrane. The other options are less likely to be associated with the given symptoms and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recent facial swelling and a previous rash suggest a poststreptococcal infection. The renal biopsy shows a “lumpy bumpy” granular appearance consistent with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. IgA nephropathy would show mesangial deposits, diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis would show wire-loop lesions, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis would show crescent formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The renal biopsy shows a "lumpy-bumpy" appearance, which is characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The recent history of rash and facial swelling supports the diagnosis. IgA nephropathy would show mesangial proliferation on biopsy. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis would show more severe histologic changes on biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The picture shows a "lumpy-bumpy" appearance, which is characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. The patient’s history of a rash suggests a post-streptococcal infection. IgA nephropathy presents as mesangial proliferation and thickening of the basement membrane. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis present with crescent formation, which is not seen in the picture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The information provided suggests a diagnosis of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, which is associated with a classic triad of symptoms: hematuria, facial edema, and hypertension. The biopsy confirms the diagnosis, showing glomerular hypercellularity and subepithelial humps. IgA nephropathy typically presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, and diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis have different histological findings on biopsy.
